issue.title: Compile Jade within my Jade

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug – robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
I have been using client-side templates recently.  I realized I couldn't figure out how to do something easily in Jade which seems like a fairly natural thing to do.

I wanted to precompile Jade templates on the server and ship them with the rendered file.  In effect, compile Jade from within Jade, capturing the compiled function as a string so it can ship.

In HTML you usually do "microtemplates" like this:

``` html
<script type="text/template" id="cool-template">
    p Hello World!
</script>
```

with a corresponding script like this:

``` javascript
var template = jade.compile(
    document.getElementById('cool-template'),
    {client: true, compileDebug: false}
);

document.getElementById('insert-here').innerHTML = template();
```

I don't like this because (a) you have to send the whole 40k jade source file to the client, and (b) you waste time on the client side compiling a template that could be compiled and cached on the server.

I would expect a feature like this in Jade:

``` jade
h1 Some cool dynamic content
 p#insert-here

script
  | var template =
  compile coolTemplate
  | document.getElementById('insert-here').innerHTML = template();

block coolTemplate
  p Hello World!
```

where `compile` would automagically turn the `coolTemplate` block into a _compiled_ function, ready to run.  It would obviously need to return the function as a string so it could be shipped in the template.

I'm not saying this is the exact syntax to use, but the nearest I can figure out otherwise is to try to pass the jade instance as a local from express, do `jade.compile`, and then use `toString` on the resulting function.  This is about as gross as it gets.

issue.title: Deprecate implicit text-only for script and style

repository.name: pug
repository.description: Pug – robust, elegant, feature rich template engine for Node.js

issue.body:
closes #875

If we can remove this feature (probably in `0.32.0`) then it will simplify a lot of code and significantly reduce the amount you have to learn when you're new to node.

The first step to removing it is to deprecate it and discourage people from using it, so this pull request logs a warning whenever someone relies on this feature.  Dealing with the fallout from this will also help to gauge how many people we're going to annoy by removing this feature.

Crucially, once we actually remove the feature altogether, we will be able to write templates that do things like:

``` jade
script
  import foo.js
```

which would be enormously useful.

body:
Perhaps I'm confused, but I've always viewed jade as a very fancy "replacement" for html. To me, the `script` and `style` tags being implicit text blocks makes sense. I'm not sure why or how using the following makes sense. Is this really the more common use case for jade?

``` jade
script
    import whatever
```

Is this just for express or node.js systems? My dev team uses jade as a template language for everything. We're not always using express/node as our server. Often times it's just static html served through nginx or even django. We use Jade, Less, and CoffeeScript to create the output we post to the server.

Just trying to understand the why on this since it is not backwards compatible.

It's for 2 reasons:
- having special cases makes jade harder to learn and more complicated
- implicit text blocks prevent you from using any sort of jade code in your script/style blocks, which can sometimes be useful

I'm rolling with it. 
But to me, the "special case" mirrors the "special case" in the html which jade represents. 
In other words, it made more sense to me for `script.` and `style.` to switch away from implicit text blocks than the other way around, since jade is a representation of html anyway.

The thing is that jade doesn't **just** mirror the special cases of html, we have the option of improving the experience.  As @slang800 says, it's about two things.  The case of `import` and equally filters like `:coffee` are a really good use case.  It's slightly more verbose, but more explicit to have:

``` jade
script
  :coffee
    # coffee script here
```

than

``` jade
:coffee
  # coffee script here
```

I'd like to move towards the more explicit option, partly because it would allow things like:

``` jade
pre
  code
    :coffee
      # coffee script here
```

which wouldn't work very well at the moment.

The other thing is that the most likely case for large ish text blocks in examples is code snippets, but in the real world they happen all the time.  Because we make the `.` implicit for script and style elements, we hide it's existence from the vast majority of new users.  Lots of people end up writing jade like:

``` jade
p
  | Imagine this
  | was a much
  | longer piece
  | of text and not
  | just one with
  | lots of line breaks
```

Which is fine to read, but way too slow to type, so people give up.

I think it's better to think of `jade` as a language for writing XML templates that just happens to have some pretty cool stuff to support some of HTML's extensions.

Thanks for the explanations (and hard work), @ForbesLindesay and @slang800. I do see your points, and I love writing `jade`. This might seem silly, but this is changing and expanding the way I view its uses.
